stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 'Grand Sand Badland' level, focusing on implementing and debugging the physics for swinging saloon doors. He also polished a duel minigame with a character named Boshy, implemented a system to pitch individual sound effects, and reviewed community-submitted dialogue for an anti-save-state feature.

development_findings.summary: The 'Grand Sand Badland' level is facing memory limitations, which restricts the addition of new characters and influenced the decision to scrap a horseshoe minigame.
development_findings.quote: We kind of have an issue with this level in that we're kind of out of memory. So I don't really want to add new characters if we can prevent that.

development_findings.summary: A significant technical challenge with the saloon door physics was resolved by realizing the code was using the object's own facing angle instead of the angle relative to Mario.
development_findings.quote: It was all because I used fucking face angle instead of angle to Mario. I think it was. Whoops.

development_findings.summary: Kaze refactored the audio engine to allow for pitching individual sounds. He designed a new, efficient system that has no performance cost unless the pitching feature is actively being used.
development_findings.quote: We need to change the frequency scale of this differently somehow... Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes.

development_findings.summary: The game's performance is limited by the N64's Reality Signal Processor (RSP), a significant technical constraint. Contributor Sauraen is working on an optimization called F3DX to address this.
Based on feedback from Lilaa, Kaze added a 3-2-1 countdown to the Boshy duel minigame to make it feel fairer and give the player more warning.
development_findings.quote: You definitely need more time before the fire and some indicators. Like a countdown?

development_findings.summary: A gag was implemented where the bartender Koopa's hat grows taller with each star collected in the level, creating a subtle, progressive visual change.
The team uses an anti-save-state detection system that triggers a rapping Yoshi to appear, discouraging players from cheating. The rap lyrics are crowdsourced from the community.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes in objectively and unemotionally considering all criticism, even if he ultimately rejects it.
context_findings.quote: Leaving a comment, critiquing whatever I made is always good. There's always a good chance that I will just say, well, your criticism is stupid, I'll ignore it. But there's also a good chance that I'll seriously look at it and reconsider my decisions.

context_findings.summary: Kaze dislikes self-inserting characters into his games, viewing it as cringe.
context_findings.quote: I think self inserts is a little cringe. If you can't get enough of me you can keep watching my stream.

context_findings.summary: Kaze's design philosophy prioritizes creating new experiences for the player, rather than just new levels that rely on vanilla mechanics.
context_findings.quote: Brody's necks are very much just like here's a level go play in it. It's not like here's a new experience go experience it.

context_findings.summary: While Kaze has opinions on other creators' work (like Star Revenge), he deliberately avoids public negativity, preferring to let others enjoy things he may not personally like.
context_findings.quote: I don't want to talk poorly about Brody attacks cuz like I don't think there's any benefit to that and I don't want to be an asshole for no reason. My decision is to just let other people enjoy it.

context_findings.summary: Kaze mentions his wife Zeina's family is very religious, giving him some familiarity with religious traditions.
context_findings.quote: Zayn outside of the family is also very religious in the house. They have, like, at least 20 pictures of Jesus around. So I am somewhat familiar with, like, religion, religious tradition.

context_findings.summary: Kaze works a professional job at a game studio that uses Unreal Engine, which influences his development environment choices (e.g., avoiding his work version of Visual Studio on stream).

biobak.summary: Biobak is reworking the graphics for Course 11, starting with a container model that Kaze praised for its depth and weathered look.
biobak.quote: He just started reworking course 11 and this already looks insane... It's crazy. Looks so much better already. It looks like it has so much depth. I mean, it's weathered. It looks really good.

biobak.summary: Biobak provided direct feedback on the saloon doors, calling them a "shower curtain" and suggesting they be made smaller, a change Kaze immediately implemented.
biobak.quote: This is a shower curtain... you thinking just like the inner part here?

zeina.summary: Zeina is creating textures for the in-game signs.

key_stories.title: The Swinging Saloon Door Physics
key_stories.summary: Kaze struggled to program the physics for swinging saloon doors, which kept rotating the wrong way. After a period of frustration and a model redesign based on team feedback, he found the solution was a single incorrect variable in his physics calculation.
key_stories.challenge: The saloon doors in the western level were not reacting realistically to Mario's interactions, specifically rotating in the wrong direction when pushed or punched.
key_stories.process: Kaze first implemented the basic swinging physics but spent a long time debugging the directional logic. He tried inverting signs and admitted to randomly changing code out of frustration. During this process, he also took feedback from Biobak to redesign the door models to be smaller and more visually appealing before finally finding the logical error in his code.
key_stories.outcome: After much trial and error, Kaze discovered the bug was caused by using the door's own facing angle in the physics calculation instead of the angle between the door and Mario. Correcting this variable fixed the physics, resulting in functional, interactive doors.
key_stories.key_quote: Dude, the doors go the wrong direction again. Are you fucking kidding me? What what the fuck am I doing wrong here?

key_stories.title: Polishing the Boshy Duel
key_stories.summary: After receiving feedback from Lilaa that a duel minigame was too abrupt, Kaze added a 3-2-1 countdown. This small addition significantly improved the player experience by making the encounter feel more fair and clearly telegraphed.
key_stories.challenge: A duel minigame felt abrupt and unfair when the player lost.
key_stories.process: Contributor Lilaa pointed out that the fail state happened too quickly. Kaze immediately agreed with the feedback and brainstormed a solution, deciding on a countdown. He then implemented the timer, added sound effects, and tweaked the duel's timing.
key_stories.outcome: The duel now has a 3-2-1 visual and audio countdown before the opponent fires, making the timing clearer and the minigame feel more fair and polished.
key_stories.key_quote: You definitely need more time before the fire and some indicators.

key_stories.title: The Pitch-Perfect Audio Engine
key_stories.summary: To make character voices unique, Kaze needed to pitch individual sound effects. He refactored the audio engine, replacing an old system with a new, highly efficient one that has no performance impact unless used, demonstrating his focus on optimization.
key_stories.challenge: Kaze needed a way to change the pitch of individual sound effects, like Boshy's voice, without adding significant performance overhead to the audio engine.
key_stories.process: Kaze first investigated the existing audio code, identifying and removing a previous, inefficient implementation. He then designed a new system based on modifying the sound's frequency scale, ensuring it added no processing cost when not in use. After implementing and testing the core feature, he expanded it to be controllable via dialogue box commands.
key_stories.outcome: Kaze successfully implemented a new, efficient system for pitching sounds. It was immediately used to lower Boshy's voice and was integrated into the dialogue system for future use. The process also involved cleaning up and optimizing old, duplicated audio code.
key_stories.key_quote: Every time you program something, you want it to be free of cost. If you're not using that part of codes.

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that contributor Sauraen is working on a new F3DX implementation to address the fact that the game is RSP-bottlenecked, which is a major performance issue.
questions: Can you explain in simpler terms what the RSP bottleneck is and how it limits the game?
What is F3DX and how does Sauraen's work help solve this problem?
How critical is this optimization for the project's success, especially for performance on original N64 hardware?

open_questions.context: Kaze frequently receives high-quality feedback from Lilaa and offered to buy her a new PC because her current one is slow. He also mentions the team hangs out in a voice channel hosted by Dan.
questions: What is the typical collaboration workflow for the team?
How are creative decisions made when there are disagreements?
Lilaa seems to be a key contributor. What is her official role on the team and how did she get involved?
Can you tell us more about the team dynamic in these voice channel hangouts?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions that his professional job is at a game studio where he uses Unreal Engine.
questions: How does your experience with modern tools like Unreal Engine influence your approach to N64 development?
Does your professional work ever inspire ideas for your ROM hacks, or vice versa?
How do you balance the time and mental energy between your day job and a massive project like this?

open_questions.context: Biobak is praised for his graphical rework of a model in Course 11, which Kaze says "already looks insane."
questions: What was the original vision for Course 11, and why did it need a graphical rework?
What is the new artistic direction Biobak is taking with the level?
How does this level fit into the game's overall progression and world?

open_questions.context: Kaze mentions a "short hack" he made with someone named Eiza/Aeza and that he plans to make a video about it.
questions: Who is Eiza/Aeza and what was your collaboration like?
What was the concept behind this short hack?
What did you learn from that project that you might be applying to RTYI?
